Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mechanics and Structural Polymorphism of Bacterial Flagellar Assemblies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to assemble self-limited structures and material that undergo large-scale structural changes in response to changing environmental conditions such as temperature, solution properties, or imposed force. As a basic building block the project will utilize bacterial flagella, a helical polymer which acts as a nanoscale spring and exhibits non-monotonic force-extension relationship that is not commonly found in synthetic materials. To achieve the goal the project will utilize a combination of experimental, computational and theoretical tools to elucidate the behavior of flagella based materials at three levels of hierarchy. First, the project will characterize and model the mechanics of individual flagella, as well as chimeric flagella engineered to achieve new polymorphic switching responses. Second, will be to generate, characterize, and control attractive interactions between a pair of flagella. Finally, these same attractive interactions will be used to assemble flagellar bundles or ropes consisting of thousands of flagella.

This study holds the promise to generate nano-structured, responsive fibrous materials with well-controlled mechanical and structural properties, in which conformational changes of individual monomeric units at Angstrom scales cooperatively cascade across multiple lengthscales to produce macroscopic mechanical changes in millimeter-sized materials. The educational and research component of this project will be integrated by expanding an REU program to hold an annual "Theory Meets Experiment" symposium for undergraduates participating in summer research at Brandeis and University of Massachusetts, to expose novice researchers to the distinct and complementary methods of theoretical and experimental research in soft materials. In addition, a partnership will be explored with Jennifer Sabin, architect, designer, and lecturer at the University of Pennsylvania School of Design in order to explore the relationship between complex biopolymer assembly motifs and a state-of-the-art textile design and fabrication process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Development of polymer-based materials has had a remarkable impact on the society over the past half a century. The properties of conventional chemically synthesized polymers that have a shape of flexible thin treads have been extensively studied and are mostly well understood.  We have initiated development of an entirely new category of biologically inspired polymers that have a perfectly rigid shape but whose curvature varies along their contour length. These biopolymers are purified from bacterial flagella which are long helical filaments that spin at very high frequency in order to power motility of diverse prokaryotic bacteria. We have demonstrated that such filaments can be reconstituted in vitro and assembled into novel rigid polymeric filaments with precisely prescribed rigid 3D shape. Changing suspension conditions such as temperature makes it is possible to induce mechanical transitions between multiple conformational states. We have examined mechanical properties of flagellar suspensions and demonstrated that the viscoelasticity of the suspension greatly depends on the shape of the constituent rigid filaments. In a separete effort, using single molecule techniques such as optical tweezers, we have assembled bundles of biological polymers one filament at a time. The filaments were held together in a bundle by a suspension of depleting molecules. Subsequently we have examined the mechanical properties of such hierarchical filamentous bundles. Previous work has assumed that coupling between such filaments is dominated by weak hydrodynamic interactions and thus individual units within a bundle can freely slide past each other in order to minimize the free energy of the overall structure. Our experiments revealed an entirely new regime in which two mutually adhering filaments behave like molecular Velcro. Consequently, the forces associated with interfilament sliding is orders of magnitude stronger and is highly reminiscent of highly conventional solid-like friction that is found in everyday life. We have developed a theoretical model that quantitatively explains our experimental measurements and predicts strategies for tuning the sliding friction of adhering biological filaments.
